comment.author: 22968943@N05
comment._content: I cannot say I can disagree, but that intake on the top is pretty far forward isn't it?  Every picture I've seen of a C-47 has had that intake further back.

comment.author: 23099031@N07
comment._content:
B-25B.  The C-47 had a strut on either side of the wheel, while the B-25 had the strut inboard of the wheel.  Also, the C-47/DC-3 did not have landing gear bay doors (that dark rectangle just above the wheel)...the landing gear pivoted forward into the engine nacelle.  

The B-D model had the turbocharger intake lush with the lip of the cowling...Turbochargers on later models were located higher on the cowling and further aft.  Probably not a C/D model as they had an inflatable black rubber de-icer boot on the leading edge of the wing (look above the prop).

comment.author: 72103051@N00
comment._content:
Really cool photo.

I have to agree that 1940s film looked pretty darn great.  The detail is amazing and you can read the lettering on the propeller.  The highlights look to be fairly bright in the scene, but they aren't blown out like you would often get with many digital cameras.

I really love the coloration with the deep tones and gradient of the sky, the black of the propeller.

This is classic and very cool.

comment.author: 92653143@N00
comment._content: The Pilot is standing in front of an A-20B Havoc - The A-20B was produced by Douglas starting in late 1941 through late 1942.  The give-away is the position of the carburetor scoop - it's nearly flush with the front of the cowling. Also, the engine pictured is an Wright twin row R-2600 - note the ignition harness, the DC3/C47 used the single row R-1820 (DC3) or the single row R-1830 (C-47). And finally, it is definitely not a B-25 since the B-25 was manufactured by North American Aviation.
